Graphical abstract Hydrocarboxylation of alkynes with CO and H2O free of auxiliary additive. Pd-catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes with CO and H2O is a promising alternative for one-step synthesis of α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids advantageous with 100 % atom-economy, but suffering from rapid catalyst deactivation and unavoidable side reactions like polymerization and hydration while the auxiliary acid-additive is required as a co-catalyst. Herein, free of any auxiliary acid-additive and under mild conditions (0.5 MPa, 60 °C, 3 h), a flexible zwitterionic phosphine of L1 containing a mono-phosphino-fragment and a hydrophilic sulfonate group (–SO3 -) conferred to Pd(OAc)2 catalyst efficient performance for hydroxycarbonylation of terminal alkynes, affording the branched α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids in the yields of 85 ∼ 91 % with 100 % regioselectivity. In addition, the developed L1-Pd(OAc)2 system was so stable that it could be recycled for 30 runs with well-maintained activity and selectivity, which proved the most active and stable to date under acid-additive-free condition. Keywords Hydroxycarbonylation Zwitterionic phosphines Carbonylation Co-catalysis Palladium catalysts α,β-Unsaturated carboxylic acids Data availability I have shared the link to my data at the Attach File step 1 Introduction Carboxylic acids make up a significant proportion of the commercially available building blocks, due to the specific chemical characteristics of involved COOH– functional group, such as acidity, polarity, hydrophilia properties, which have a wide range of applications in materials, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, the food industry and other manufactured chemicals [1–10]. At present, with the increasing demand for the applications of carboxylic acids, the market is anticipated to grow by more than 5 % from 2017 to 2022 to achieve a projected price of $11 billion [8,11]. Notably, transition metal catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation of unsaturated substrates (alkenes or alkynes) has attracted much attention for straight-forward synthesis of carboxylic acids from low-cost materials, which represents a vibrant topic in homogeneous catalysis and green chemistry with industrial significance [12–23]. To date, various transition metal catalyst, such as palladium [8,12,15,16,21] (Scheme 1 -a), platinum, ruthenium cobalt [24,25] (Scheme 1-b) have been applied to catalyze this reaction, in which phosphine-modified Pd-catalytic systems have been proved more efficient and widely explored by M. Beller [26], W. Reppe [27], and other groups [28,29] However, in the reported pioneering work, the presence of acid-additives was universally required, which not only resulted in the degradation of the phosphine-modified Pd-catalysts as well as the corrosive problem, but also induced the side-reactions of alkyne polymerization and hydroxylation [29–31]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop the acid-additive-free Pd catalytic systems. In 2019, our group firstly reported an Pd-catalytic system for hydrocarboxylation of alkynes under acid-free condition by applying an amphiphilic zwitterionic SO3 --tailed phosphine [32] (Scheme 1-c, L2), which revealed that the incorporated SO3 --unit could synergetically activate H2O via hydrogen bonding interaction. So far, the examples of acid-free Pd-catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation of unsaturated substrates are very few and highly demanded with focus not only on the activity and chemo-/regio-selectivity of the applied Pd-catalysts but also on the stability and durability for practical uses [13,33–37]. Herein, without addition of any auxiliary additive, another zwitterionic phosphine of L1 with structural flexibility, derived from BINAP, was found to confer to Pd(OAc)2 not only the high activity and excellent chem-/regio-selectivity but also good stability, corresponding to 85 ∼ 91 % yields of the branched α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids and 30-run recycling uses (Scheme 1). The control experiments and the DFT calculations were conducted to disclose the role of L1 in synergetically activating H2O due to its unique composition and structural configuration. For comparison, the other sulfonate-tailed zwitterionic phosphines of L2-L4 were investigated in parallel. 2 Results and discussion The amphiphilic SO3 --tailed phosphines of L1-L4 were synthesized according to the method reported by our group [32,35]. The Pd-catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene with CO and H2O was investigated as a model reaction under different conditions. After screening the reaction conditions in terms of solvent, CO-pressure and reaction time (see Table S1 in SI), 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene with 100 % regio-selectivity to the branched product of 2-phenylacrylic acid was obtained under the optimized conditions [Pd(OAc)2 0.5 mol%, L1/Pd = 4/1 M ratio), CO 0.5 MPa, NMP as solvent, 60 °C, 3 h.] (Table 1 , Entry 1). The decrease of temperature from 60 °C to 40 °C led to the reduced conversion down to 44 % (Entry 2). At room temperature, if the reaction time was prolonged from 3 h up to 8 h, 92 % conversion of phenylacetylene was obtained (Entry 3). In homogeneous catalysis, the involved ligand is usually required to be in excess relative to the transition metal. Firstly, the presence of excess ligand can guarantee the stability of Pd)-catalyst against deactivation upon timely coordination to Pd(0/II)-center; Secondly, the inherent degradation of the ligand itself is unavoidable during the reaction. Herein, four-fold of L1 relative to Pd(OAc)2 was required to guarantee the activity and stability of the Pd-catalyst. The screening of Pd-precursors including Pd(OAc)2, Pd(CF3COO)2, PdCl2, and Pd2(dba)3 indicated that Pd(OAc)2 was the best choice. And the use of Pd(CF3COO)2 instead of Pd(OAc)2 had a discernible influence on the chemo-selectivity of this reaction, leading to the formation of the by-products of acetophenone and but-3-en-1-yne-1,3-diyldibenzene with selectivity of 13 % (Entry 4). Under the same conditions, PdCl2 and Pd2(dba)3 just exhibited the poor activity (Entries 5 and 6). Then under the optimal reaction conditions in hand, the effects of the different SO3 --tailed phosphines of L2-L4 were explored. Evidently, the ligands of L1 and L3 are featured with flexible structural configuration wherein the PPh2-fragment and the phosphonium-linked SO3 --unit could rotate to intramolecularly accommodate Pd-center and the substrates (alkyne, CO, H2O). In comparison, L2 is featured with the rigid skeleton, in which the intramolecular accommodation of Pd-center around the PPh2-fragment and SO3 --unit is sterically forbidden, just leading to the formation of an intermolecularly L2-SO3 -–co-ligated binuclear Pd-complex as reported by us before [32]. L4 is the analogue of L1 but in the format of a typical ionic salt with free and mobile MeSO3 --counteranion. As a result, L1-Pd(OAc)2 system corresponded to 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene towards 2-phenylacrylic acid (a) without the formation of any linear product of cinnamic acid (Entry 1). With L2-Pd(OAc)2 system, no activity was observed under the same conditions (Entry 7 vs 1); Only when the temperature increased to 120 °C, 67 % of phenylacetylene was converted to the α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids with B/L ratio of 90/10 (Entry 8 vs 1). The use of L3-Pd(OAc)2 system just led to very poor conversion of phenylacetylene (6 %) at 60 °C, and then 92 % of conversion with B/L of 90/10 at 120 °C (Entries 9 and 10). L4-Pd(OAc)2 system exhibited no any activity either at 60 °C or at 120 °C (Entries 11 and 12). As for L1 and L4, although they were featured with nearly the identical electronic property for the incorporated PPh2-fragment [31P NMR (δ): L1, −14.81; L4, −14.99] [35], the obtained reaction results with them were completely different (Entries 1 vs 11), implying that the steric effect around the PPh2-fragment rather than the inherent electronic effect of PPh2-fragment played the dominant role in modifying the performance of Pd-catalyst in terms of activity and regio-selectivity. And due to the enhanced steric hindrance around PPh2-fragment in L1, even 100 % regio-selectivity to the branched product was observed. In contrast, as the diphosphines of BINAP, Xantphos and DPEphos as the parent molecules of L1-L4 were applied respectively, no reaction occurred under such acid-free conditions (Entries 13–15). Only with the presence of MSA (methanesulfonic acid), BINAP-Pd(OAc)2 system corresponded to 92 % of phenylacetylene towards the α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids with B/L ratio of 90/10 (Entry 16). Accordingly, the ligands with flexible structures as well as the zwitterionic nature without free SO3 --unit such as L1 and L3 were in favor to the performance of Pd(OAc)2 catalyst. Comparatively, L1, with more steric hindrance at periphery of the PPh2-fragment and SO3 --unit, corresponded to much higher activity and better selectivity than L3 (Entry 1 vs 10). In addition, the scaled-up synthesis of 2-phenylacryllic acid by using 30 mmol of phenylacetylene was achieved at Pd-concentration of 0.05 mol%, which corresponded to a TON of 2060 (gacid/gPd) for the Pd-catalyst. Interestingly, this reaction also could be conducted at atmospheric CO-pressure in a 100 mL three-necked round-bottomed flask (see Scheme S1 in SI). Under the applied conditions [Pd(OAc)2 0.05 mmo l, L1/Pd = 4:1 M ratio, phenylacetylene 30 mmol, H2O 36 mmol, CO atmosphere, NMP 6 mL, 12 h, RT], with L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system free of additive, 99 % conversion of phenylacetylene and 100 % regioselectivity to 2-phenylacrylic acid were obtained. However, under the atmospheric CO-pressure, the Pd-catalyst deactivated slowly to precipitate Pd-black upon reaction. On the other hand, it was indicated that the solvent of NMP played an indispensable role for the high performance of L1-Pd(OAc)2 system (see Table S1 in SI). NMP as an N-containing ligand with exposed carbonyl-group might timely protect the Pd-catalyst (via weak-coordination) against deactivation and synergetically help proton-transfer, then expediting the reaction rate. It should be noted that under any conditions indicated in Table 1 and Table S1 (see SI), no product of 2-phenyl succinic acid derived from bis-hydroxycarbonylation was found, which suggested that L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system under additive-free condition be selectively active to mono-hydroxycarbonylation. The recycling uses of L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst were shown in Fig. 1 . Upon 30 runs, L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst remained stable without activity loss or Pd-black precipitation, giving 2-phenylacrylic acid in the yield of ∼ 97 % in each run and corresponding to the cumulative TON of 30,800 (gacid /gPd). Notably, upon every 10-run, L1 had to be added additionally to guarantee the activity and stability of the Pd-catalyst, due to the unavoidable degradation of L1 under the applied conditions. Otherwise, without the additional addition of L1, the activity of L1-Pd(OAc)2 dropped gradually upon 12-run cycles (see Fig. S1 in SI). This catalyst was one of the most active and stable systems as reported in the literature to date. However, this recycling experiment only showed that L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst was indeed stable. Since the high polarity and the high boiling point of the product of 2-phenylacrylic acid, the practical isolation and recovery of L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst for the recycling uses was not available at present stage. To elucidate the excellent catalytic performance of L1-Pd(OAc)2 system in this hydroxycarbonylation free of additive, the control experiments and DFT calculations were conducted as depicted in Scheme 2 . The competition experiments of H2O against MeOH in Scheme 2-A demonstrated that, when the mixture of H2O and MeOH (1:1 M ratio, 1.2 equiv. to phenylacetylene) were added together in this reaction, only 2-phenylacrylic acid was obtained in 86 % yield, suggesting that L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst exhibit the exclusive activation ability towards H2O rather than MeOH due to the strong affinity (hydrophilicity) of SO3 --unit to H2O. Then the in situ 1H NMR spectral analysis (in CD3OD) demonstrated that the characteristic signal of H2O at 4.87 ppm [Scheme 2-B-(1)] shifted to 5.11 ppm when Pd(OAc)2 was added into the mixture of H2O and L1 [Scheme 2-B-(2)] whereas the signal of CD3OD at 3.31 ppm retained unchanged, which further convinced that H2O (rather than MeOH) could be effectively activated by L1-Pd(OAc)2 system. However, when L4 with mobile MeSO3 --counteranion was subjected to the same analysis, the signal of H2O at 4.87 ppm was unchanged at all [Scheme 2-B-(3)], which means no interaction between H2O and L4-Pd(OAc)2 system and then consistently accounted for the failed reaction as observed in Entries 11 and 12 of Table 1. These results verified that the synergetic activation of H2O by L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system only happened when SO3 --group were conveniently confined around Pd-center without free mobility, then leading to the successful hydroxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene with H2O without the aid of any auxiliary additive. Then the DFT (density functional theory) calculations [38], as depicted in Fig. 2 (see the additional information given in Table S2 of SI) further gave the supportive information on the synergetic activation of H2O by L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system. Initially, L1-based Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system is defined as a zero-point as energy reference in the energy calculation. When this catalytic system is applied to complex with CO and H2O, the optimized geometric structure of intermediate-A with the lowest energy level (ΔG=6.5 kcal/mol) shows that the strong hydrogen-bond (H ⋯O distance of 1.44 Å) between the oxygen-atom of −SO3 -group and hydrogen-atom of H2O is developed, wherein the Pd-P bond distance of 2.50 Å, the Pd-H bond distance of 1.66 Å, the Pd-CO bond distance of 1.96 Å and the Pd-O bond distance of 2.17 Å are all in the rational range. The transformation from L1-based Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system to palladium hydride (Pd-H) intermediate of A only requires an energy barrier of 6.59 kcal/mol, which indicates that the formation of A is potentially available with the favorable energy level. Accordingly, the DFT calculations (Fig. 2) and the 1H NMR analysis (Schem 2-C) both suggested that, over L1-based Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system, the H2O-molecule coordinated (i.e. trapped) to Pd-center can be synergetically activated by the confined SO3 --group via hydrogen-bond interaction to facilitate the formation of Pd-H intermediate of A, corresponding to the successful hydroxycarbonylation under acid-free and mild conditions. Based on the above results, a plausible mechanism for the hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes over L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system free of additive is proposed in Scheme 3 . Initially, the palladium-hydride intermediate of A is formed upon complexation of Pd(OAc)2 with L1 and H2O under CO atmosphere, in which Pd-center is readily four-coordinated by the phosphino-fragment in L1, CO and H2O. The intermolecular hydrogen bonding interaction between hydrophilic group –SO3 − in L1 and H2O as well as the flexible BINAP-based-backbone of L1 greatly facilitates the formation of A-intermediate with the favorable energy level (ΔG=6.59 kcal/mol) as depicted in DFT calculations (Fig. 2). The synergetic activation of Pd-coordinated H2O by the hydrophilic SO3 --group in L1 has also been proved by the 1H NMR spectral analysis (Scheme 2-B). However, the Pd-H characteristic peak of A was not detectable by the in situ FT-IR analysis (as provided in Scheme S2-A in SI) probably due to the transiency of A-intermediate. Then the rapid addition of C≡C triple-bond of aryl alkyne with Pd-H bond in A results in the formation of vinylpalladium intermediates of B, in which B-1 is more kinetically favored than B-2 because of the convenient steric arrangement around Pd-sphere. Then, the 100 % regioselectivity of the branched product following Markovnikov’s rule is determined in this elementary reaction from A to B-1. Subsequently, CO-insertion into Pd-vinyl bond of B-1 allows the formation of an acyl-Pd intermediate of C-1 in CO atmosphere. Finally, the intramolecular elimination of C-1 upon H2O-hydrolysis results in the formation of a branched α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acid, along with the regeneration of A. And the secondary kinetic isotope effect (SKIE) with the KH/KD ratio of 1.16 (as provided in Scheme S2-B in SI) also convinced that the H2O-hydrolysis of C-1 as the rate-determining step in L1-Pd(OAc)2 involved catalytic cycle was greatly facilitated. Evidently, with L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system, the pre-activation of H2O by Pd-center as well as the hydrophilic SO3 --group is conducible to the formation of Pd-H intermediate (A) and rapid hydrolysis of C-1, which accounts for the efficient hydroxycarbonylation free of auxiliary additive. The scope of alkyne substrates for the hydroxycarbonylation catalyzed by L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system was explored in Table 2 . It was found that, with phenylacetylene derivatives as the substrates, 100 % regio-selectivity to the branched carboxylic acids were obtained without exception. And the variation of the substituent on phenyl ring with different steric and electronic effects had no influence on the conversion and the regioselectivity. Notably, when the internal alkyne of 1-phenyl propyne was applied in this carbonylation, 92 % of 1-phenyl propyne was converted to the α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, with the branched regio-selectivity of 64 % (B/L=64/36. With diphenylacetylene as a substrate, the reaction failed completely even at 100 °C due to the inert reactivity of this super-conjugated compound. As for the aliphatic alkynes such as 1-octyne and 1-hexyne, no rection happened. 3 Experimental Section 3.1 Reagents and analysis The chemical reagents were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and Alfa Aesar China, and used as received. The 1H and 31P NMR spectra were recorded by a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer. Gas chromatography (GC) analysis was performed on a SHIMADZU-2014 equipped with a DM-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm). The analyses GC-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) which equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) were recorded on an Agilent 6890 instrument equipped with an Agilent 5973 mass selective detector. The FT-IR spectra were recorded by a Nicolet NEXUS 670 spectrometer. The TG/DTG analyses were performed on a TGA2 (SF) from METTLER TOLEDO. 3.2 General procedures for Pd-catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation In a typical experiment, Pd-precursor (0.015 mmol, 0.5 mol%), ligand (L1-L4, 0.03 mmol, 1 mol%), phenylacetylene (or the other alkyne, 3.0 mmol) and H2O (3.6 mmol) were added in sequence into 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, 3.0 mL). Then the obtained mixture was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and pressured by 0.5 MPa CO. Then the rection mixture was heated at 60 °C in oil-bath for 3h under magnetic stirring at 600 rpm. Upon completion, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature and slowly depressurized. The solution was analyzed by GC to determine the conversion of substrates (n-dodecane as internal standard) and the selectivity of products (normalization method), and the products were further identified by GC–MS and 1H/13C NMR spectrometer. 3.3 In situ 1H NMR spectroscopic characterization In a typical experiment, firstly, Pd-precursor (0.015 mmol), ligand (L1-L4, 0.015 mmol) and the H2O (0.015 mmol) was added into 5 mm heavy precision pressure/vacuum valve NMR sample tube (500 MHz). Then under the CO atmosphere (0.8 MPa), the mixture dissolved in CD3OD was heated at 60 °C in an oil-bath for 15 min, and then immediately tested by the 1H NMR spectrometer. 3.4 Computational methods The structural optimization of L1 and A were conducted by using DFT method on the B3LYP functional in Gaussian 16 software.[38] The basis set of H, C, O, S, P were 6-31G*, and the basis set of Pd was pseudopotential SDD. Only the one imaginary frequency matched the reaction path, indicating that the optimized intermediate structures were reasonable. The Cartesian coordinates of optimized structures of L1 and A can be found in Table S2 of SI. 4 Conclusions In this work, the efficient hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes with CO and H2O catalyzed by L1-Pd(OAc)2 system was achieved under the mild reaction conditions, advantageous with 100 % atom-economy, no requirement of auxiliary acid additives, and high yields of the branched α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids with 100 % regioselectivity. In comparison to the rigid Xantphos-derived ligand of L2, the flexible BINAP-derived L1 conferred to Pd(OAc)2 more efficient catalytic performance due to its ability to intramolecularly confine SO3 −-unit and H2O around Pd-center, which facilitated the activation of H2O. Due to the absence of acid-additive, the side-reactions like polymerization and hydration of alkynes were completely inhibited and the stability of L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalyst was dramatically improved. coredata.dc:description: Pd-catalyzed hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes with CO and H2O is a promising alternative for one-step synthesis of α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids advantageous with 100 % atom-economy, but suffering from rapid catalyst deactivation and unavoidable side reactions like polymerization and hydration while the auxiliary acid-additive is required as a co-catalyst. Herein, free of any auxiliary acid-additive and under mild conditions (0.5 MPa, 60 °C, 3 h), a flexible zwitterionic phosphine of L1 containing a mono-phosphino-fragment and a hydrophilic sulfonate group (–SO3 -) conferred to Pd(OAc)2 catalyst efficient performance for hydroxycarbonylation of terminal alkynes, affording the branched α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids in the yields of 85 ∼ 91 % with 100 % regioselectivity. In addition, the developed L1-Pd(OAc)2 system was so stable that it could be recycled for 30 runs with well-maintained activity and selectivity, which proved the most active and stable to date under acid-additive-free condition.

coredata.dc:title: Active and stable Pd-catalyst modified by sulfonate-tailed zwitterionic phosphine for hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes free of any additive
